newsitem.title: HUNGARY: BUDAPEST RESTAURANT CLOSED DOWN OVER $6,000 DINNER.
newsitem.headline: BUDAPEST RESTAURANT CLOSED DOWN OVER $6,000 DINNER.

text.p: A Budapest restaurant which charged two Danish tourists and two women companions more than $6,000 for dinner and drinks was closed down for three months by local authorities on Tuesday.
The Budapest Fifth District Council decided to close the restaurant pending further investigation.

"We have closed the restaurant provisionally for 90 days while we conduct a more thorough investigation to decide whether we will close it permanently," council spokeswoman Judit Xantus told Hungarian television.

Consumer protection authorities said last week they had begun a legal proceeding against the Dreher Halaszcsarda after Preben Olsen lodged a complaint at a tourist office, saying he had been charged more than 1 million forints, newspapers said.
However, a successful claim against the restaurant's owner woulds only result in maximum fine of 30,000 forints ($176) under Hungarian law.
The U.S. Embassy in Budapest earlier this month warned about overpricing and strongarm tactics employed in some Budapest cafes and nightclubs, although the Halaszcsarda was not among them.
Xantus added that her authority, which covers Budapest's main commercial district, would conduct checks on 250 establishments in the area.
